article.title: Four kinetic energy formulas for studying the interaction of energetic ions with carbon nanotubes

multiple_choice_question.text: What are the two main types of effects on a damaged carbon nanotube caused by the mass and charge of an incident ion?
choices: Kinetic energy-dependent and kinetic energy-independent effects.

multiple_choice_question.text: Two methods are discussed for studying the stopping of ions in carbon nanotubes. Which statement correctly describes these methods?
choices: One method calculates the number of energetic recoils hitting a metal layer below the nanotube, while the other analyzes the change in nanotube temperature.
One method calculates the number of energetic recoils hitting a metal layer below the nanotube, while the other calculates the ion-deposited energy in the nanotube.
One method measures the penetration depth of the ions into the nanotube, while the other analyzes the change in nanotube electrical conductivity.
One method measures the penetration depth of the ions into the nanotube, while the other calculates the ion-deposited energy in the nanotube.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significant finding about the stopping power of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) at incident ion energies below 1 keV?
choices: The MWCNTs exhibit negligible stopping power at these energies, allowing ions to pass through them with minimal energy loss.
The MWCNTs exhibit maximum stopping power at these energies, effectively blocking all ions from penetrating through them.
The MWCNTs exhibit a gradual increase in stopping power with increasing ion energy in this range.
The MWCNTs exhibit a gradual decrease in stopping power with increasing ion energy in this range.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the formula E₀ - E_penetrating = (4Mm/(M+m)²) * Σ Eᵢ sin²(θᵢ₊₁/2) describe?
choices: The relationship between the incident ion energy and the temperature change in the carbon nanotube.
The relationship between the incident ion energy and the number of defects created in the carbon nanotube.
The relationship between the incident ion energy and the ion-deposited energy within the carbon nanotube.
The relationship between the incident ion energy and the sputtering yield of carbon atoms from the nanotube.
